In your world, you could determine the basic needs of individuals based on factors such as age, health, and occupation. For example, a young, healthy adult with a physically demanding job may require more resources than an elderly person with a sedentary job. You could then allocate resources accordingly, using a combination of manual tracking (such as a ledger system) and digital tracking (such as a computer program).

To incentivize work, you could offer additional resources or privileges to individuals who contribute to the community through their work. For example, someone who works in agriculture may be able to earn extra resources by producing a surplus of crops, while someone who works in a factory may be able to earn extra resources by meeting production quotas. You could track these contributions and reward them accordingly, using a similar tracking system as described above.
